title: City news: Whitbread, Terra Firma, Conviviality Retail, Paddy Power
text:
City news: Whitbread, Terra Firma, Conviviality Retail, Paddy Power City news: Whitbread, Terra Firma, Conviviality Retail, Paddy Power ALL the latest updates from City & Business… PUBLISHED: 20:46, Tue, Sep 8, 2015 | UPDATED: 21:02, Tue, Sep 8, 2015 VisMedia HIGHER COSTA: Boss Andy Harrison Whitbread: Wage hike grounds down hospitality firm 
WHITBREAD will increase prices and cut costs to offset the hit from implementing the national living wage. 
The Premier Inn and Costa coffee operator is expected to spend around £15-20million a year bumping up wages. 
It has about 34,000 employees earning less than £7.20 an hour, half of whom are over 25. Related articles City news: John Lewis, Apple, City Three Peaks Challenge,... 
It is not cutting jobs but will take on fewer additional staff over the next couple of years. 
More details will be announced with its half-year results next month. Premier Inn like-for-like sales grew by 4.3 per cent over 11 weeks to August 13 and sales at Costa outlets open at least a year rose 4 per cent. 
Total sales rose by 3.3 per cent but trading was “softer than expected”. Shares fell 75p to 4636p. 
Chief Andy Harrison said: “We are on track to deliver full year expectations as well as ambitious growth milestones.” Terra Firma: Justin King has a new castle 
EX Sainsbury’s boss Justin King has joined private equity firm Terra Firma – his first major role since leaving the chain in 2014. 
King, credited with reviving Sainsbury’s fortunes, has become vice chairman and head of portfolio businesses at City tycoon Guy Hands’s Terra, which controls Odeon UCI Cinemas, Wyevale Garden Centres and Four Seasons Health Care. 
He had taken advisory roles with Manor Grand Prix and 2 Sisters Food Group. 
King said: “I am looking forward to playing my part in Terra Firma’s hands-on approach to transforming businesses.” Conviviality Retail: ‘Mixer’ cause to celebrate 
CHAMPAGNE corks popped at Conviviality Retail as shares in the company behind Bargain Booze and Wine Rack soared 20 per cent after it agreed to buy drinks wholesaler Matthew Clark in a deal worth £200million. 
Buying Clark, which supplies about 17,000 on-trade outlets including pubs, bars, hotels and restaurants, from its joint owners Punch Taverns and Hertford Cellars, will create a business with combined annual sales of over £1.1billion. 
The deal will be financed by a £130million placing and £80million to be drawn down under new debt facilities. Conviviality shares rose 32½p to 187½p. 
Chief executive Diana Hunter said: “This will accelerate our strategy of expanding our wholesaling expertise into new markets and channels. 
“We can serve a diverse range of customers and build our wine and spirit volumes further while strengthening our retail channel. 
“The acquisition will create a major player in the UK drinks wholesale market and we believe it will give rise to significant potential synergies.” Paddy Power: Gaming merger a safe bet 
PADDY Power and Betfair have agreed a £6billion union to create a global powerhouse in online gaming. 
The two companies, who set out plans to merge last month, said they expect the combination to generate annual cost savings of £50million. 
Paddy Power shareholders will receive a special dividend of £58million before the deal is completed. 
They will then hold 52 per cent of the new company Paddy Power Betfair, with Betfair’s investors owning 48 per cent. 
Betfair’s chief executive Breon Corcoran and Paddy Power chairman Gary McGann will retain those roles in the merged business, while Paddy’s chief executive Andy McCue will become chief operating officer. 
The deal is due to be completed in the first quarter of 2016. McGann said: “The merger will create a company of world class capability and people. 
“The combination of Breon, Andy and their colleagues comprises ‘the A team’ in the business with the ambition to create a unique global player in a very dynamic industry.” Related articles
